This report was prepared by D. Purka and C. Litwin, Infrastructure Division, Mekong Department.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During  the  Asian  Development  Bank’s  (ADB)  operational  missions  in  2002,  the 
Government of Cambodia requested technical assistance (TA) for building the capacity of 
Electricity Authority of Cambodia (EAC), the new independent electricity sector regulator, to 
develop transparent policies, guidelines, and procedures for setting tariffs for electricity supply. 
While it was not included in the Country Strategy and Program Update (CSPU), the advisory TA 
was endorsed by the Vice President (Operations 1) on 3 June 2003 and is now included in the 
2003 program. An ADB Fact-Finding Mission visited Cambodia during 4–17 June 2003 and 
reached  an  understanding  with  the  Government  on  the  objective,  scope,  cost,  financing, 
implementation arrangements, and the consultants’ terms of reference for the TA.1 The TA 
framework is attached as Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.    Damaged by years of war and neglect, the electricity supply system in Cambodia is 
presently  fragmented  and  extremely  varied.  A  sizable  portion  of  demand  continues  to  be 
supplied  from  small  and  medium-size  generators  owned  by  consumers  and  small  private 
enterprises. This means that the national electricity supply is unreliable and operators cannot 
capture economies of scale. The average retail electricity tariff in Phnom Penh is $0.15 per 
kilowatt-hour (kWh), while tariffs in provincial areas outside of Phnom Penh range from $0.30 to 
$0.92/kWh. These tariffs rank among the highest in the region.  Despite  the  Government's 
efforts, its institutions require further development, and power supply is costly, unreliable, and 
limited mostly to urban areas and towns. Over the past decade, assistance from ADB and other 
international  finance  institutions  has  primarily  focused  on  rehabilitating  generation  and 
distribution systems in Phnom Penh and developing similar systems in larger provincial towns to 
reduce the cost of electricity. In recent years, lenders have provided assistance for institutional 
strengthening to clarify the sector roles of the Government and provincial authorities, promote 
private sector participation under a more transparent framework, commercialize state-owned 
power utilities and reduce their operational inefficiencies, and facilitate subregional integration. 
 
3.    The new Electricity Law of Cambodia, promulgated in 2001, defined the management 
and regulation of activities in relation to the supply and consumption of electricity. In effect, the 
law  outlined  the  institutional  restructuring  of  the  sector  by  clarifying  and  segregating  the 
Government's role as a regulator, policy maker, electricity supplier, and investor. One of the 
main purposes of the law was to establish the EAC as an autonomous public agency to regulate 
electricity  services  and  to  govern  the  relation  between  the  delivery,  receipt,  and  use  of 
electricity. EAC’s main duties are licensing participants and approving their tariffs and other 
terms and conditions of electric power service. EAC will ensure that the provision of electric 
power  services  will  be  governed  by  the  principles  of  efficiency,  quality,  continuity,  and 
transparency.  The  Ministry  of  Industry,  Mines  and  Energy  (MIME)  would  maintain  its 
responsibility for policy management and for strategies and planning for the Government in the 
power sector.  
 
4.    ADB’s  CSPU  for  Cambodia  indicates  that  ADB  will  support  the  development  of 
infrastructure and promote an enabling environment for private sector participation. In 2000, 
ADB approved the Provincial  Power Supply Project2 to support Electricité du Cambodge’s

2 
(EDC)  rehabilitation  of  electricity  supply  systems  in  eight  towns  to  stimulate  the  local 
economies.  The  upgraded  systems  will  lower  electricity  costs  under  EDC  supply,  provide 
reliable electricity and strengthen the local network so that entrepreneurs can connect to the 
supply. ADB is currently preparing the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) Power Transmission 
Project, which will construct a 220-kilovolt transmission line between Viet Nam and Cambodia. 
The GMS Project will allow Cambodia to import substantially cheaper electricity to the Phnom 
Penh area. Upgraded systems and imports from Cambodia will help reduce the cost and 
improve the quality of electricity service.     
 
5.    However, the Electricity Law stipulates it is EAC’s responsibility to set tariffs to ensure 
that consumers will benefit from these improvements and will be protected from arbitrary pricing.  
Until the law was passed and EAC established, the Government permitted full cost recovery 
pricing in provincial areas, while retail tariffs in Phnom Penh were not adjusted regularly for full 
cost recovery. EAC is responsible for establishing principles and policies for the operation of the 
electricity sector as well as licensing participants for reliable and safe provision of electricity to 
consumers.  Cambodia  is  in  a  unique  situation  in  that  it  already  has  substantial  private 
participation in electrification through an estimated 600–1,000 private rural electricity enterprises 
(REEs) operating on the periphery of provincial towns and in rural areas. While the REEs are 
relatively small, fragmented private sector enterprises, they provide an essential basic service in 
rural areas. Presently, REEs operate under a harsh business environment with limited access to 
capital, limited short-term operating permissions, and an uncertain regulatory environment that 
results in high tariffs. The high tariffs severely affect affordability to poor consumers and 
constrain demand, with consequential implications for rural development and poverty reduction. 
A clear tariff-setting mechanism will create incentives for the private sector to reduce costs and 
become more efficient in its operations, and, most importantly, ensure that end consumers 
benefit from investments in the sector.    
  
6.  While EAC has been operational since late 2001, it has focused its capabilities on 
issuing long-term licenses to the larger operators in Cambodia (e.g., EDC’s Phnom Penh 
operations,  EDC’s  provincial  town  service  areas,  and  independent  power  producer  [IPP] 
generators). It is only now beginning to review and issue longer-term licenses to some of the 
REEs, which will also encourage further investment and price reductions. EAC has issued the 
General Conditions of Supply in late 2002 and recently issued procedures for issuing and 
revising licenses. The license procedures include a public consultation process to review and 
comment on proposed licenses. Information of this nature is also regularly posted on its Internet 
web  site  and  physically  posted  in  service  locations.  Assistance  for  clarifying  licensing 
procedures and setting technical service standards has been provided under World Bank 
funding.  However,  EAC  has  been  unable  to  fully  develop  those  policies,  procedures  and 
guidelines for tariff setting that will promote efficiency, transparency, and affordable supply of 
electricity. ADB support is needed to strengthen EAC’s capabilities as an effective sector 
regulator and promote good governance in the sector. A regulator’s ability to provide effective 
oversight depends significantly on the strength of its technical capabilities. Therefore, this TA 
expects  to  familiarize  EAC  with  international  good  practices  and  standards  in  regulatory 
functions. In addition, the TA will strengthen consumer and stakeholder participation in the 
process to further demonstrate the regulator’s intent to protect all consumers and promote 
transparency and accountability in the sector.

3 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
7.    The TA will strengthen EAC’s capacity to discharge its tariff-setting responsibilities 
mandated in the Electricity Law and function as an effective independent regulator of electricity 
supply in Cambodia. The TA will be realized through the following components and output:  
(i) development of transparent electricity pricing guidelines and regulatory methodology for  
tariff-setting; (ii) operational support to EAC on policies, procedures, and specific guidelines for 
effective monitoring of licensees; (iii) training on international tariff-setting methodologies and 
financial monitoring mechanisms; and (iv) stakeholder participation workshops on tariff setting 
and design of an information dissemination campaign to consumers. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.    The electricity pricing guidelines and tariff-setting strategy will be developed, presented, 
and  discussed  with  stakeholders,  taking  into  account  the  current  structure  of  Cambodia’s 
electricity market and heterogeneous type of licensees.3 Due to these attributes, two tariff 
setting procedures may need to be developed, which will be consistent with the basic economic 
principle of regulation. Once the guidelines have been developed in conjunction with EAC, the 
consultants will assist EAC staff in drafting the subdecree for MIME’s and EAC’s review and 
joint submission to the Government for approval. The subdecree, which is required by the 
Electricity Law, will outline the principles of tariff setting and what costs of electricity production 
and distribution can be recovered through the tariff.   
 
9.    The consultants will also provide operational support and in-house training for EAC staff. 
First, they will hold an in-house training seminar on key aspects of forms of economic regulation 
and applications to Cambodia. Once guidelines have been developed, the consultants will give 
EAC’s financial and technical staff on-the-job training in the processes and procedures. In 
particular, the consultants will demonstrate how Excel-based computer models can be used to 
monitor financial performance and how to analyze performance indicators. 
  
10.   Establishing an effective regulatory mechanism requires interaction and participation 
with  all  stakeholders:  the  Government,  public  utilities,  private  sector  operators,  advocacy 
groups, and consumers. In drafting the guidelines, the consultants will present international 
good practices in participatory approaches in regulation, so that EAC appreciates the potential 
pitfalls of tariff setting, which changes are often politically charged issues and have a direct 
impact on the poor. The consultants will assist EAC plan, design, and carry out a public 
stakeholder workshop on methods of regulation, proposed tariff-setting methodologies, and 
potential impacts on actual tariffs. The consultants will discuss with EAC the feedback collected 
from these meetings and determine any midcourse adjustments to address concerns before the 
guidelines are finalized. As part of drafting the guidelines, the consultants will assist EAC in 
designing an information campaign to disseminate the results and explain the tariff-setting 
process.  These  workshops  will  help  strengthen  public  confidence  that  EAC  intends  to 
transparently set tariffs that protect consumers as well as ensure that licensees can recover 
costs. It is important to note that the workshops must be driven by EAC and the consultants to 
ensure Government sense of ownership of the process and to build credibility. 
                                                 
3  Cambodia has several large licensees, including EDC and nidependent power producers, which collectively 
provide electricity to Phnom Penh and other major populated areas. However, the remainder of the provincial and 
rural areas are served by the numerous REEs. It may not be practical or possible for EAC to require (and 
subsequently review) the same detailed information from REEs as from the larger licensees.

4 
11.   The above activities constitute the first phase of  the tariff-setting process, in which 
guidelines in the form of the subdecree will be developed and presented to the Government for 
approval. Once the subdecree is approved, there is the risk that EAC staff’s technical and 
financial skills may still be insufficient to carry out the detailed review and tariff-setting process. 
To mitigate this risk, further TA is planned to assist EAC through the implementation phase of 
the tariff-setting mechanisms. While EAC has indicated its intent to pursue other grant funding 
for this next phase (and commits to keep ADB informed of progress), an allocation to finance 
this subsequent assistance has been made from the expected loan proceeds of the GMS 
Transmission Project, scheduled for Board presentation in the fourth quarter of 2003. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The  total  cost  of  the  TA  is  estimated  at  $300,000  equivalent  comprising  foreign 
exchange  of  $229,500  and  local  currency  equivalent  of  $70,500.  The  Government  has 
requested ADB to finance the entire foreign exchange cost of $229,500 and $10,500 equivalent 
of the local currency cost. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by the Governance 
Cooperation Fund, to be administered by ADB. The Executing Agency, EAC, will finance the 
balance of the local currency cost, equivalent to $60,000, by providing office accommodations 
and  facilities,  local  communication,  counterpart  staff,  secretarial  support,  data  and  other 
information needed for the TA. Detailed cost estimates and the financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  EAC will be the Executing Agency for the TA. To ensure a close working relationship, 
the consultants will work in EAC’s offices in Phnom Penh. EAC will provide counterpart staff to 
work with the consultants and will make proper arrangements for office space, secretarial 
support, and local transportation for site visits. EAC will provide necessary assistance to the 
consultants  in  liaising  with  other  Government  ministries  and  agencies,  and  in  obtaining 
necessary data and documentation. EAC will also provide available operating and financial 
information on licensees to ensure that the consultants have a clear understanding of the 
current electricity market before making recommendations on regulatory processes.   
 
14.  The TA will require approximately 7 person-months of international consulting services.  
It will be implemented over 6 months starting in November 2003 and ending in April 2004. 
Outline terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. It is envisaged that a team 
consisting  of  a  regulatory  economist  and  a  financial  analyst  will  carry  out  the  TA.  The 
consultants will have expertise in regulating electric utilities, private sector participation, utility 
financial  analysis  and  tariff-setting  methodologies,  and  process-oriented  training.  ADB  will 
engage  a  consulting  firm  in  accordance  with  its  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants. 
Consultants will be recruited under the quality- and cost-based selection procedures, and 
simplified technical proposals will be requested. There will be no procurement under this TA. 
 
15.  Deliverables  will  be  disseminated  through  stakeholder  workshops  to  discuss  tariff 
methodologies and appropriate approaches for Cambodia, considering its unique situation. The 
workshops will help build the credibility of EAC in moving forward with its decisions, which will 
be integrated into the subdecree. In the course of the TA, EAC staff will also be trained on 
procedures for internal review, financial analysis of submissions by licensees, and decision-
making processes. Results will also be conveyed through an end-consumer dissemination 
campaign designed under the TA.

5 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $240,000 to the Government 
of Cambodia to be financed on a grant basis by the Governance Cooperation Fund for the 
purpose of Capacity Building of Electricity Authority of Cambodia, and hereby reports this action 
to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  A  team  of  international  consultants  will  carry  out  the  technical  assistance  (TA)  to 
Electricity Authority of Cambodia (EAC) over 6 months. It is envisaged that the team will consist 
of one regulatory economist (4 person-months) and one financial analyst (3 person-months). 
The regulatory economist will be the team leader and will be responsible for managing the TA 
and submitting all deliverables according to schedule. The consultants will have expertise in 
regulating electric utilities, private sector participation, utility financial analysis and tariff-setting 
methodologies, and process-oriented training. 
B.  Scope of Work 
 
2.  The work covers four major areas. The consultants must review the scope of work 
before their services start and make any recommendations to the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) to ensure completion of deliverables in a cost-effective manner.  
 
1.  Review  of  Electricity  Supply  Market  and  Proposals  for  Tariff-Setting 
Principles and Methodology 
3.  The consultants will undertake these tasks: 
 
(i)  Review  the  requirements  and  authority  provided  to  EAC  under  the 
Electricity  Law  (2001),  EAC’s  General  Conditions  of  Supply,  EAC’s 
licensing procedures, and all other information on Cambodia’s electricity 
sector. 
(ii)  Present issue-based discussion papers to EAC on various economic and 
financial  approaches  to  regulation,  tariff-setting  principles,  and 
international good practices. 
(iii)  Recommend specific tariff-setting policies and guidelines for Cambodia, 
incorporating the principles of cost recovery, efficiency, reliability, and 
transparency. The approach must consider what is an appropriate and 
practical method of tariff regulation that will cover large licensees with 
detailed information and rural electricity enterprises (REEs) with limited 
information. 
(iv)  Comment on the draft tariff application containing the public consultation 
process of tariff review and approval, and procedures for customers and 
other interested parties to comment on the applications. 
 
2.  Operational Support to EAC 
4.  The consultants’ specific tasks are as follows. 
 
(i)  Propose evidentiary requirements for tariff submission and time frame for 
decisions. Propose procedures for EAC to obtain additional information 
from licensees as necessary to evaluate tariff applications. 
(ii)  Develop Excel-based computer models for analyzing financial information 
and tariff applications from licensees. 
(iii)  Assist  EAC  officials  draft  the  Electricity  Law  subdecree  on  electricity 
pricing costs.

10  Appendix 3 
(iv)  Draft  a  uniform  and  standardized  application  for  tariff  approval  and 
submission of accounts for financial monitoring, based on International 
Accounting Standards. 
 
3.  Internal EAC Training 
5.  The consultants’ tasks are as follows. 
 
(i)  Train EAC staff on the key aspects of economic and financial regulation, 
principles, and methods. 
(ii)  Offer  training  on  how  to  evaluate  the  different  costs  of  electricity 
production and supply so that, as much as possible, uniform categories 
can be used. 
(iii)  Train financial staff to use Excel-based computer models for financial 
analysis and modeling of alternative revenue/tariff scenarios. 
(iv)  Provide training on how to apply the same computer models to facilitate 
EAC’s compliance monitoring on an ongoing basis. 
 
4.  Stakeholder Workshops and Design of Information Dissemination 
6.  The consultants’ tasks are as follows. 
 
(i)  Before finalizing the tariff-setting guidelines and subdecree, conduct a 
public  consultation  workshop  on  methods  of  regulation  and  gather 
feedback  on  the  recommended  strategy.  The  methodology  to  be 
proposed should be made available in advance to stakeholders for their 
comment. 
(ii)  Conduct at least one, or preferably 2–3 field visits or workshops with 
REEs to understand the provincial operating and business environment, 
which may affect recommendations on regulatory design. Additional field 
visits and consultations will be held as can be accommodated in the 
budget. 
(iii)  Design an information dissemination campaign for EAC to implement 
once the subdecree is approved. The campaign should be designed to 
allow for additional feedback from stakeholders (especially consumers) to 
ensure that the process is fully understood. 
 
C.  Reporting Requirements 
 
7.  Within 2 weeks of the start of services, the consultant will submit an inception report, 
which outlines the work to be undertaken and highlights any issues that require ADB’s and 
EAC’s feedback. Two months after the start, the consultant will issue an interim report, which 
will indicate progress on the scope of work and any discussion papers and presentations 
completed. Four months after the start of services, the consultant will submit a draft final report 
including (i) proposed guidelines, policies, and procedures for tariff setting; (ii) a draft subdecree 
on electricity pricing costs; (iii) Excel-based computer models for financial monitoring and 
analysis of licensees; (iv) proposed templates for financial reporting and application for tariff 
approval; (v) a summary of results of the public consultation meetings; and (vi) design of the 
information dissemination campaign. Three weeks after receiving comments from ADB and 
EAC, the consultant will submit the final report integrating such comments.
